R. 5.42 p.m. 15th March 1946. Repeated to Moscow . Foreign Office N o. 597 999999 Foreign Office telegram No. 350. Sadchikov is about 37, and after studying philosophy at Perm University 'became professor of that subject au # Moscow University. He then joined the diplomatic service and served in Tehran, and in the Commissariat for Foreign Affairs. He 'became Ambassador to Belgrade # in March 19?5. He is married and has a wife of Ukrainian origin who speaks however; no language but Russian. Sadchikov seems aole, intelligent anda shrewd observer but speaks onl^ ^ssian and a few words of French. As the Soviet Ambassador, his position in this country was one of great prominence. Before the elections last year he appeared on several occasions at political demonstrations m the Company of Sal fitoV Much was made of this by the Government in order to prove to the people of Yugoslavia that the regime enjoyed the full support of the Soviet Union. Foreign Office please pass to Tehran and Moscow as my telegrams Nos. 1 and 14 respectively. [Repeated to Tehran and Moscow under telegram Nos. 263 and 819 respectively]. Bullard No. 240 OIBTNET DISTRIBUTION FROM TEHRAN TO FOREIGN OFFICE 25th February, 1946 Repeated to Moscow D. 10,45 a.m. 25th February,1946 R. 11.45 a.m. 25th February, 1946 Z - Z - Z IMPORTANT Secret. M. Sadchikov Soviet Ambassador in Belgrade is being transferred to Tehran. Agrdment was perhaps given by Persian Prime Minister in Moscow. No application has been made by Soviet Embassy here. 2. There rill be general relief among the Persians at the removal of Maximov who was detested for his rudeness and arrogance, I should be glad to have up to date opinion on OTP^ 7T Cf., & ^ ^ith th# C«m#*nn«^^ of tbo _/^AL fy^'ce ^,11 r - ’• t ndia direc 4, £ .?S.i Jj- •f #M» r Under £ # A «* Forsl^e * 17 MAY 1844 fA|* r c# j [This telegram is of particular secrecy and Should be rr^ained by the authorise^ rjecipi^^gnd ndt passed on], (CYPHER.] rised V/nR CABINET DISTRIBUTION TEHRAN TO FOREIGN OFFICE Sir R. Bullard No, 187 13th May, 19<’4, D. 1.15 p.m. 01T 13th May,1914. Re 4.20 p.m.DBST 13th May,1944. Copies by bag to:- Moscow , Government of India Bagdad and M.E e Min. IMPORTANT CONFIDENTIAL My telegram No. ) Bolivar informs me in confidence that Soviet Government are withdrawing their Ambassador Mikhailov on the ground of ill-health and have asked for agrdment of present Counsellor and Chargd d’Affaires Maximov as Ambassador. I have little doubt that withdrawal of Mikhailov is due to his failure to induce Iranian Government to accept Soviet's offer of war material. [Copies sent to Mr. Wiltshire].[This telegram retained by the is of particular; secrecy and shpuld ^ e authorised recipient n ?i passed on]* :T ~' [EN CLAIR] ?• L't ^ 7 l ~ IceAr-t W/Jl CABI1I GT DISTRIBUTION FROM TEHRivN TO FOREIGN OFFICE Sir # R. Bullard. No. 25 Saving. 5th May, 1944. D. Un-tiaed. 5th May, 1944. R. 7.10. p.m. 12th May,. 1944. Repeated to Moscow 23 Saving . . Government of India No.37 Saving Bagdad No.63 Saving M.E.Min. Cairo No.77. Saving Soviet Ambassador recently informed his colleagues that he was leaving for Russia for medical treatment, 2, There is perhaps some ground for the suspicion of Persian officials that his departure was not due tojillness or at least not to illness alone. Present Prime minister saw the Ambassador the day after the Persian Government had refused to accept the conditions attachedto the Soviet offer of war material and found him ”looking like a man condemned to death yet maintaining that he was perfectly well. From that moment the Ambassador was never seen except presmaably by Russians. Several times I was informed by the Soviet Embassy ^hat he was better but my requests to be allowed to call on him were always refused and my American colleague and an official or . the Ministry of Foreign Affairs had similar experience. 3 Mikhailov is believed to be high up in the Party but he may have fallen into disgrace. Stalin was probably pleased with his call on the Shah.and vatn the a °Geptance of the off r of war material and a Soviet ambassador ^ho bailed to complete the transaction might well be unpopular with th- Kremlin. 4. If Mikhailov has gone for good neither the British nor the American Embassy will be sorry. He s ® ei ^ d h 9 c ? 1 ^, 2^ f cm<rm clous and we failed to get a word out of him either for or 3 against anything we saidg The Charge d'affaires Maximov, who is an old Persia hand, is a clever intriguer, hut he is human, has a sense of humour, and can often he r-gged into taking action. fConies sent to nr, Wiltshire]1 m @ H No.39 (61/9/44) Sir, XED Witfc the Compliment* »* of th^ Unde^ Secretary of State for Foreign AffaifiPITISH LEGATION TBHF - Sf£B 19M i r ' : ! J “ >- •*\ 24tb January, 1944• i ’ turU qtlV / w ^ :j w J I have the honour to report jU5%i > onsl*eur Cone tar t in Alexandrov! t ch MikhaildVJ' 45W ,^oyie t Amhassador, presented his credentials to the Shah on the 16th January. He was wearing the new diplomatic uniform. According to the Minister of Court the Shah noticed two things in particular about Monsieur Mikhailovj that his uniform with its hanging dagger recalled that of Nazi diplomatists; and that he seemed awkward and made no bow to His Majesty. rf?' LA & 2. It is early to judge, but so far M. Mikhailov has failed to come up to the expectations which I had formed after reading the latest report on him by His Majesty’s Legation in Kabul. He has certainly shown no candour, and he has failed signally to respond to my own; but allowance must be made for the fact that he has taken over his new post at a moment when Stalin appears to have a new policy viz. to support the Shah, while the Soviet Embassy has been trying with little disguise to impose upon the electors in various consti tuencies members of the party of the extreme left, the Tudeh. I have the honour to he. With the highest respect. Sir, Your most obedient, humble Servant, (Sgd.) The Right Honourable Anthony Kden, M .C ., M. P •, Foreign Office. R.W. BULLARD.(if in any case the communication of the contents of this document to any person outside Government Service is authorised, it must he paraphrased)» -A1 v . 11ed to External Department , Copies to Fo reign Offic e. CYPHER TELEGRAM. Fr om To Rptdp to* H. M« Minister, Kabul. Tehran. Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, India Office. Dated Kabul, 15.00 hours, 2nd September. 1943 Heed* 05.00 hours. 3rd September, 1943. So?.o 233.[This document must be p&r&phre-sed if communic—ted to o.ny person outside Grovernment service] ' [CYPHER] ? FROM MOSCOW TO EQREIGN OFFICE /^Cir A» Clark Kerr* DEPARTMENTAL NO. 1. D#—11 • 1 p>iii« l^t September |U—L>5 p>m> '8nd September 1945» IVo. 859 > 1st September 1943• Repeated to Tehran No. 62 of 1st September, and Kabul (unnumbered). 0:0:0:0:0 Tehran telegram No. 934 to you. Notification of withdrawal of Smirnov from Persia and his replacement by Soviet Ambassador in Kabul Mikhailov v/as published in Moscow papers on September 1st. (Foreign Office please pass Lu Kabul) • [Copies sent to Telegraph Branch India Office for repetition to Kabul][This document must be paraphrased if communicated to any person outside Government service] DEPARTlvIBNTiiL NO, 1, [CYPnGR] FROM TEHRAN TO FOREIGN OFFICE D. 8*00 p.uu 26th August, 1943# R. -1.00 a.Bu 27th august, 1943# Sir R* Bullard No. 931- 26th August, 19^3* Repeated to Foreign New Delhi No. J10 Minister of State, Cairo No. 131 Minbranch Bagdad No. 193 Kabul No. 18 Moscow No. 56. 0 0 0 0 Soviet Ambassador Smirnov at present in Moscow is being replaced by Soviet ambassador Kabul. According to Maisky S. has resigned on the ground of ill health and on recovery is to be employed in Ministry of Foreign Affairs. Smirnov s health it is true has never been good in Tehran, Operation for appendicitis v/hich was performed here did not effect the expected cure. His departure is generally regretted. His relations with this Legation were particularly good. 2. I feel that report by British Legation Kabul on his successor would be very useful. [Copies sent to Mr. armstrong].

location.physicalLocation: British Library: India Office Records and Private Papers

physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in approximate chronological order from the rear to the front of the file.

Foliation: the foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 15; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. A previous foliation sequence between ff 8-15, which is also circled, has been superseded and therefore crossed out.

mods.abstract: Telegraphic correspondence reporting on appointments to, and departures to the post of Soviet Ambassador to Persia [Iran]. The file’s principal correspondents are: HM Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary to Persia at Tehran, Reader William Bullard; HM Ambassador to the Soviet Union at Moscow, Archibald Clark Kerr; the Foreign Office.The file includes a divider, which gives a list of correspondence references contained in the file by year. This is placed at the back of the correspondence.

name.namePart: Ambassador of Soviet Russia to Iran
